statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
The little guys got it done 
again for No. 21 Notre Dame.
article.headline: Quinn leads team for third-straight game
article.linkText: Backcourt paces No. 21 Irish in ugly win
article.story:
SOUTH BEND, Ind. (AP) -- Charleston Southern had one of the worst
scoring nights in the 36-year history of the Joyce Center.

      Notre Dame wasn't a whole lot better.

      After shooting 28.5 percent through the first 27 minutes, Chris
Quinn scored 10 of his 17 points and Notre Dame shot 8-of-13 down
the stretch to beat the Buccaneers 54-38 on Friday night.

      "Ugly game or not, we still came out with a 'W,'" said Irish
guard Chris Thomas, who added 15 points. "It was good to see us
hold a team under 40 points."

      The 38 points were the second fewest allowed at the Joyce
Center, which opened for the 1968-69 season. The low was in a 50-35
Notre Dame win over Rice on Jan. 23, 1984. The Irish (3-0) held the
Buccaneers (1-2) to just 27 percent shooting in the second half,
and 33 percent for the game.

      Notre Dame coach Mike Brey was more concerned about the lack of
production from his big men. Notre Dame's three starting forwards
combined for 12 points on 4-of-14 shooting and the Buccaneers
outscored the Irish 20-18 inside and outrebounded the Irish 34-32.

      "If our big guys are getting in the way and they're not in a
rhythm, get the heck out of the way of the guards," he said.

      The Buccaneers tied it at 29 on Thomas Harrison's wide-open
3-pointer with 13:30 left. But Jordan Cornette scored on a rebound
off a miss by Thomas to start a 14-0 run in which six different
players scored for the Irish.

      Quinn, who was 1-of-5 shooting in the first half, was 6-of-8 in
the second half.

      "I missed a lot of shots I should have made, but I kept my head
up," Quinn said. "Coach Brey looked at me at halftime and said,
`Just go out there and have fun.' That's what I tried to do."

      Notre Dame, which trailed by seven in the first half, extended
the lead to 43-29 when Dennis Latimore scored inside. Kurtis Rice,
who led Charleston Southern with 10 points and 11 rebounds, scored
on a reverse layup for Charleston Southern to end a scoreless
streak of 7:34.

      But Quinn made a pair of 3-pointers and drove the baseline for a
basket inside to give the Irish a 51-33 lead.

      "I thought Quinn got away from us," Charleston Southern coach
Jim Platt said.

      The Buccaneers didn't attempt a free throw.

      "Maybe that's how nonphysical our big guys are," Brey said.
"They didn't put anyone on the line."
